name: methyl_4-phenylbenzoate
source: Beilstein F. K.; Beilsteins Handbuch der Organischen Chemie. Springer; Berlin; 1972.
Reason: 4-phenylbenzoate has a melting point influenced by functional groups relative to the base of benzene, which melts at 5.5 °C. The basic unit for this compound can be considered the benzene ring, which has a melting point of 5.5 °C. The phenyl group introduces a rigid structure and additional molecular weight, estimated at +20 °C. The methyl group reduces the melting point due to the reduced molecular weight and van der Waals interactions, estimated at -5 °C. The carbamate group (1-carbam) will increase the melting point due to its ability to form intermolecular hydrogen bonds and increase molecular weight. Quantitatively, the benzene base might be considered to have a melting point around 50 degrees Celsius, based on the fact that benzene itself has a melting point around that value. The phenyl group introduces a rigid structure and additional molecular weight, estimated at +20 degrees Celsius. The methyl group reduces the melting point due to the reduced molecular weight and van der Waals interactions, estimated at -5 degrees Celsius. Lastly, the carbamate group can lead to a significant increase, of about +20 degrees Celsius. The effects are additive.
